config.question: Which of the following best explains why many Americans were reluctant to enter World War I at the outset?

choices.content: A large number of Americans were progressives who pursued peace and did not easily accept war.
Most Americans questioned American military preparedness to enter a war of that scale.
Most Americans believed that the United States would lose a war against the more powerful Germany.
Public opinion was sharply divided about supporting the Allied Powers or the Central Powers.

answer_3.response: Consider This: In general, Americans accepted neutrality. They saw no need to enter the conflict, especially after the Allies in September 1914 halted the first German drive toward Paris. America had a tradition of avoiding foreign entanglements. In addition, war would end reform. It consumed money and attention; it inflamed emotions. See L.O. 24.3 Toward War.
